snippet: A school director's effort to teach young people to be more polite lights up the Twittersphere and makes Melissa Eddy, the IHT's Berlin correspondent, question our expectations of our children.
abstract: A school director's effort to teach young people to be more polite lights up the Twittersphere and makes Melissa Eddy, the IHT's Berlin correspondent, question our expectations of our children.
lead_paragraph: Trending on Twitter in Germany Monday morning - right up there with the #superbowl and New York Giants - was "Grüss Gott," roughly translated as "God's Greetings," and traditionally the way Bavarians and other southern Germans, and most Austrians, greet one another. The greeting has the nation buzzing after the director in a middle school in the southern city of Passau posted a notice banning the more casual "Hallo" from the premises in favor of "Grüss Gott," which she considers to be more polite. (The casual German expression for bye, "Tschüss" has also been jettisoned in favor of the more traditional "Auf Wiedersehen.")
